definition:
For any $A\subseteq{\mathbb{N}}$ we denote
$S(n):=\sum\limits_{k=1}^n \frac 1k$. The values
$${\overline{\delta}}(A)=\liminf_{n\to\infty} \frac{\sum\limits_{k\in A; k\leq n} \frac 1k}{S(n)} \qquad {\underline{\delta}}(A) = \limsup_{n\to\infty}
\frac{\sum\limits_{k\in A; k\leq n} \frac 1k}{S(n)}$$ are called *lower*
and *upper logarithmic density* of $A$. If
${\overline{\delta}}(A)={\underline{\delta}}(A)$ we denote this value by
$\delta(A)$ and call it the *logarithmic density* of $A$.

Logarithmic density can be equivalently defined as follows: If the limit
$$\delta(A)={\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}} \frac{\sum\limits_{k\in A; k\leq n} \frac 1k}{S(n)},$$
exists, then it is called logarithmic density of $A$.

By the well-known $\gamma = {\lim\limits_{n\to\infty}} S(n) - \ln n$
defining Euler’s constant, we can see that the denominator in the above
definitions can be replaced by $\ln n$.

[1]{}

M. Kolibiar, A. Legéň, T. Šalát, and Š. Znám. . Alfa, Bratislava, 1992.
(in Slovak)

H. H. Ostmann. . Springer-Verlag, Berlin-Göttingen-Heidelberg, 1956.

J. Steuding. .

G. Tenenbaum. . , Cambridge, 1995.
